text: today's status: making progress on encoding with ffmpeg, I think I found the right options for ffmpeg and hope to be able to test it today and work out bugs tomorrow

I've got all the ffmpeg tools and codecs in the proper directories and code ready to call it with (I think) roughly correct options, but I'm hitting a wall on actually being allowed to execute ffmpeg... this is going outside the Android APIs, since there's no SDK that I know of for video encoding, so I'm trying to run binaries on the hardware itself, which KitKat doesn't apparently allow without rooting the device. Tomorrow I'll plan on putting in a useful error message for that situation and rooting my Nexus 5 so I can continue developing. I imagine Google's internal devices are all rooted (or rootable) so hopefully that won't present a problem for them being able to test it (if rooting even succeeds in making it possible to create this video).
should i find out if rooting is an issue w. google?

I'm not a huge fan of rooting my primary dev device (since I want it to be a good test device for standard, production-capable apps) but this situation seems to need it. I'll research alternatives before I go through with it, though, maybe there's another workaround that I didn't immediately find
Sure, might be good to pass that information along so they're aware of the situation.
The main message is that we're looking into using the FFMPEG encoder, to create video, which appears to need root permission in order to run
Hey <@U02F8TTPU> I spent a bit of time last night looking at jcodec, maybe we team up for a bit tomorrow and try to get to the bottom of the brokenness? (Considering ffmpeg is an issue)
(I'm in samsung meetings but wanted to float that)
Sounds great <@U026PHQ3J>, I would have liked to go with jcodec first, but the lack of functional sample code scared me off. I'll be around all day tomorrow!
<@U02F8TTPU>: still send that heads up to Ryan?
